</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>, consisting of the SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion(s) and L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2-[(2-dimethylaminoethylimino)-methyl]-phenolate, have been studied by X-ray diffraction and solid state NMR spectroscopy. The metal cations in these complexes have different coordination modes: Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> is almost square-planar, the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation in <ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold> is pentacoordinated, whereas Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> is penta- and hexacoordinated in [<ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>]. The different coordination of the metal cations influences the chemical shifts of the metal cations and also the nitrogen atoms. These chemical shifts can be correlated with the M–N and M–O bond lengths (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Different coordination of the metal cations in model Schiff base complexes influences the chemical shifts of the metal and nitrogen atoms, and well correlates with the M-N and M-O bond lengths.

Abstract

Three model metal complexes: Ni(NCS)L, Zn2(NCS)2L2  and Cd2(NCS)2L2 , consisting of the SCN- anion(s) and L=2-[(2-dimethylaminoethylimino)-methyl]-phenolate, have been studied by X-ray diffraction and solid state NMR spectroscopy. The metal cations in these complexes have different coordination modes: Ni2+ is almost square-planar, the Zn2+ cation in Zn2(NCS)2L2  is pentacoordinated, whereas Cd2+ is penta- and hexacoordinated in [Cd2(NCS)2L2 ]. The different coordination of the metal cations influences the chemical shifts of the metal cations and also the nitrogen atoms. These chemical shifts can be correlated with the M-N and M-O bond lengths (M=Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+).

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The condensation reaction of aromatic aldehydes and primary amines leads to imines known as Schiff bases. The Schiff bases obtained from different substituted salicylaldehydes can form intra- and intermolecular hydrogen bonds. These bonds mostly determine the chemical and physicochemical properties of the Schiff bases . Enantiomeric Schiff bases and their optically active metal complexes have found many applications in biology, clinical and analytical studies . The Schiff base metal complexes are also very useful model systems in chelate chemistry. The metal ion in such complexes can be coordinated by the imine nitrogen atom and also by the other active centres present in the molecule. This can lead to many interesting catalytic properties . The coordination sphere around the metal ion and its conformation ability are the major factors in specific biological functions such as, for example, metalloenzymes active in many oxygen related processes . The thermochromic and photochromic properties of some Schiff bases have been subject of both theoretical and practical studies . Specially, thermochromic salicylaldehyde derivatives are very promising candidates in material engineering to obtain novel conductive materials with proton motion coupled with electron conductivity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The condensation reaction of aromatic aldehydes and primary amines leads to imines known as Schiff bases. The Schiff bases obtained from different substituted salicylaldehydes can form intra- and intermolecular hydrogen bonds. These bonds mostly determine the chemical and physicochemical properties of the Schiff bases . Enantiomeric Schiff bases and their optically active metal complexes have found many applications in biology, clinical and analytical studies . The Schiff base metal complexes are also very useful model systems in chelate chemistry. The metal ion in such complexes can be coordinated by the imine nitrogen atom and also by the other active centres present in the molecule. This can lead to many interesting catalytic properties . The coordination sphere around the metal ion and its conformation ability are the major factors in specific biological functions such as, for example, metalloenzymes active in many oxygen related processes . The thermochromic and photochromic properties of some Schiff bases have been subject of both theoretical and practical studies . Specially, thermochromic salicylaldehyde derivatives are very promising candidates in material engineering to obtain novel conductive materials with proton motion coupled with electron conductivity.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Previously, we investigated several Schiff bases with neutral and ionic hydrogen bonds . It was found, on the basis of NMR and X-ray measurements, that the proton position in the hydrogen bond bridge depends on both the character and position of substituents in the aromatic ring and on the character of the base used. The proton transfer process, from the oxygen atom to the nitrogen site was investigated . To identify the major differences between both types of hydrogen bonds, we performed systematic experimental charge density analyses of several ionic and neutral Schiff bases in the solid state .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Previously, we investigated several Schiff bases with neutral and ionic hydrogen bonds . It was found, on the basis of NMR and X-ray measurements, that the proton position in the hydrogen bond bridge depends on both the character and position of substituents in the aromatic ring and on the character of the base used. The proton transfer process, from the oxygen atom to the nitrogen site was investigated . To identify the major differences between both types of hydrogen bonds, we performed systematic experimental charge density analyses of several ionic and neutral Schiff bases in the solid state .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">In the present study we have focused on three model complexes of Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> with (SCN)<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and a Schiff base ligand (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>) [HL, L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2-[(2-dimethylaminoethylimino)-methyl]-phenolate] resulting in <ce:bold>ML(NCS)</ce:bold> type complexes where M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>. In this work we would like to demonstrate the structural and spectroscopic properties of different metal coordination modes. To determine the structures of the complexes we have applied X-ray diffraction and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C, <ce:sup loc="pre">15</ce:sup>N and <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd CPMAS NMR spectroscopy. A very important aspect of this study is the comparison of the analytical potential of both methods in structural elucidation. In such a comparison we have to remember that NMR results are obtained from easy accessible powder samples, whereas the X-ray method requires single crystals. The X-ray structure of the nickel complex has already been published , but since it seemed to be a little doubtful we have repeated the structural investigations of this structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the present study we have focused on three model complexes of Ni2+, Zn2+ and Cd2+ with (SCN)- and a Schiff base ligand ( ) [HL, L=2-[(2-dimethylaminoethylimino)-methyl]-phenolate] resulting in ML(NCS) type complexes where M=Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+. In this work we would like to demonstrate the structural and spectroscopic properties of different metal coordination modes. To determine the structures of the complexes we have applied X-ray diffraction and 13C, 15N and 113Cd CPMAS NMR spectroscopy. A very important aspect of this study is the comparison of the analytical potential of both methods in structural elucidation. In such a comparison we have to remember that NMR results are obtained from easy accessible powder samples, whereas the X-ray method requires single crystals. The X-ray structure of the nickel complex has already been published , but since it seemed to be a little doubtful we have repeated the structural investigations of this structure.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The Schiff base ligand [LH] was prepared by the condensation of salicylaldehyde with <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-dimethylethane-1,2-diamine in methanol solution at room temperature . The <ce:bold>M(NCS)L</ce:bold> complexes were prepared by mixing equimolar solutions of the appropriate metal acetates with the ligand [HL] and NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(SCN) in methanol solution .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis

The Schiff base ligand [LH] was prepared by the condensation of salicylaldehyde with N,N'-dimethylethane-1,2-diamine in methanol solution at room temperature . The M(NCS)L complexes were prepared by mixing equimolar solutions of the appropriate metal acetates with the ligand [HL] and NH4(SCN) in methanol solution .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>NMR measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">All liquid state NMR spectra have been run on a Bruker DRX Avance 500 spectrometer using a 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm TBI Z-gradient probehead at room temperature. The assignment of the signals has been done on the basis of GCOSY, GHSQC and GHMBC experiments using standard Bruker procedures for both acquisition and data processing. The chemical shifts of the proton and carbon signals are referred to the internal TMS standard, whereas nitrogen-15 chemical shifts are referred to external nitromethane used as the standard. The CPMAS spectra were collected at room temperature using a Bruker 500 Avance II spectrometer equipped with a 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm MAS <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H/BB probehead. Typical CPMAS experimental conditions for the <ce:sup loc="pre">15</ce:sup>N measurements were as follows: spectral width 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kHz, acquisition time 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ms, contact time 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ms, rotation rate 6–10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kHz, relaxation delay up to 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s depending on the relaxation properties of the sample. Up to 32<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>000 scans were collected to obtain good quality spectra. For the carbon CPMAS experiment the following conditions were applied: spectral width 31.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kHz, acquisition time 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ms, contact time 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ms, rotation rate 10–11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kHz, relaxation delay 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s and up to 512 scans were collected. A two times longer relaxation delay for some nitrogen spectra was applied to avoid a possible oversaturation effect. For short contact time CH spectra a contact time of 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μs was applied. The <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd NMR spectrum in the solid state was recorded under similar conditions as the nitrogen spectra. Originally this spectrum was referenced to cadmium acetate (<ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−707.34<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm) and then the chemical shift was recalculated to the dimethylcadmium scale. A similar procedure was done for solution cadmium spectra. The CP sequence was made by a ramped proton pulse and continuous wave heteroatom irradiation. During the acquisition time modulated TPPM-15 decoupling was used.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
NMR measurements

All liquid state NMR spectra have been run on a Bruker DRX Avance 500 spectrometer using a 5mm TBI Z-gradient probehead at room temperature. The assignment of the signals has been done on the basis of GCOSY, GHSQC and GHMBC experiments using standard Bruker procedures for both acquisition and data processing. The chemical shifts of the proton and carbon signals are referred to the internal TMS standard, whereas nitrogen-15 chemical shifts are referred to external nitromethane used as the standard. The CPMAS spectra were collected at room temperature using a Bruker 500 Avance II spectrometer equipped with a 4mm MAS 1H/BB probehead. Typical CPMAS experimental conditions for the 15N measurements were as follows: spectral width 25kHz, acquisition time 30ms, contact time 4ms, rotation rate 6-10kHz, relaxation delay up to 20s depending on the relaxation properties of the sample. Up to 32000 scans were collected to obtain good quality spectra. For the carbon CPMAS experiment the following conditions were applied: spectral width 31.25kHz, acquisition time 30ms, contact time 2ms, rotation rate 10-11kHz, relaxation delay 10s and up to 512 scans were collected. A two times longer relaxation delay for some nitrogen spectra was applied to avoid a possible oversaturation effect. For short contact time CH spectra a contact time of 40μs was applied. The 113Cd NMR spectrum in the solid state was recorded under similar conditions as the nitrogen spectra. Originally this spectrum was referenced to cadmium acetate (δ =-707.34ppm) and then the chemical shift was recalculated to the dimethylcadmium scale. A similar procedure was done for solution cadmium spectra. The CP sequence was made by a ramped proton pulse and continuous wave heteroatom irradiation. During the acquisition time modulated TPPM-15 decoupling was used.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray diffraction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction measurements were crystallized from methanol. Data collection for single crystals of all compounds (<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) was carried out using a single crystal X-ray κ-axis KM4CCD diffractometer  with Mo Kα radiation and a graphite monochromator, and applying the omega scan technique. Single crystals were positioned 65<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm from the CCD 1024<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1024 pix. camera. The 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> angle ranges were extended from <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 2° up to 57° for <ce:bold>Ni(NCS)L</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold> and up to 50° for <ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>. Each frame was measured at a 0.8° angle interval and a counting time of 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s. Multi-scan absorption correction was applied . Data reduction and analysis were carried out with the CRYSALIS RED software .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray diffraction

Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction measurements were crystallized from methanol. Data collection for single crystals of all compounds (T =100K) was carried out using a single crystal X-ray κ-axis KM4CCD diffractometer  with Mo Kα radiation and a graphite monochromator, and applying the omega scan technique. Single crystals were positioned 65mm from the CCD 1024×1024 pix. camera. The 2θ angle ranges were extended from ca. 2° up to 57° for Ni(NCS)L and Cd2(NCS)2L2  and up to 50° for Zn2(NCS)2L2 . Each frame was measured at a 0.8° angle interval and a counting time of 20s. Multi-scan absorption correction was applied . Data reduction and analysis were carried out with the CRYSALIS RED software .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">All structures were solved by direct methods  and refined using <ce:small-caps>Shelxl</ce:small-caps>
. The refinement was based on squared structure factors (<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) for all reflections except those with very negative <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. Most of the hydrogen atoms were located in idealized averaged geometrical positions, however some hydrogen atoms were found from difference electron density maps. Scattering factors were taken from Tables 6.1.1.4 and 4.2.4.2 in Ref. . 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor> includes experimental details for all measured structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: All structures were solved by direct methods  and refined using Shelxl . The refinement was based on squared structure factors (F 2) for all reflections except those with very negative F 2. Most of the hydrogen atoms were located in idealized averaged geometrical positions, however some hydrogen atoms were found from difference electron density maps. Scattering factors were taken from Tables 6.1.1.4 and 4.2.4.2 in Ref. .   includes experimental details for all measured structures.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Solid state NMR results</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The results of <ce:sup loc="pre">15</ce:sup>N CP MAS measurements of the three metal acetate complexes with the (SCN)<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion are collected in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>. The assignment of the primary nitrogen signals has been done on the basis of the analysis of the chemical shifts values. The most upfield signals were assigned to the di-methylamino function, the range of chemical shifts from −350 to −370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is very typical for this fragment. The downfield signals in all the spectra have very important distinctive marks; for example, a high chemical shift anisotropy, which is demonstrated by the presence of strong rotational side bands. In all the compounds, these signals can be assigned to imino moieties. Additionally, this assignment can be confirmed by the <ce:sup loc="pre">15</ce:sup>N GHMBC spectrum of the cadmium complex in the DMSO solution. Only two signals have been detected in this spectrum. Both of them showed correlation with CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> groups, so they must be assigned to the ligand nitrogen atoms (−122.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm signal for the Schiff base group and −355.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm for the nitrogen of the amine group). In this experiment the (SCN) nitrogen signal is invisible. The nitrogen chemical shift for the SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> fragment depends on the chemical bonds present in the molecule. For the aliphatic thiocyanates (EtSCN), the nitrogen chemical shift is −102.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, whereas for the isothiocyanate (Et(NCS)), this signal is shifted upfield to −277.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm . The ionic species NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> has a nitrogen signal almost at the middle of this range, for example, K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">N</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm. The nitrogen chemical shifts of this fragment differ very much for the investigated complexes compared with simple model compounds, which means that the chemical bonds present in the complexes are much more complicated than those observed in simple aliphatic thiocyanates and isothiocyanates.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Solid state NMR results

The results of 15N CP MAS measurements of the three metal acetate complexes with the (SCN)- ion are collected in  . The assignment of the primary nitrogen signals has been done on the basis of the analysis of the chemical shifts values. The most upfield signals were assigned to the di-methylamino function, the range of chemical shifts from -350 to -370ppm is very typical for this fragment. The downfield signals in all the spectra have very important distinctive marks; for example, a high chemical shift anisotropy, which is demonstrated by the presence of strong rotational side bands. In all the compounds, these signals can be assigned to imino moieties. Additionally, this assignment can be confirmed by the 15N GHMBC spectrum of the cadmium complex in the DMSO solution. Only two signals have been detected in this spectrum. Both of them showed correlation with CH2 groups, so they must be assigned to the ligand nitrogen atoms (-122.4ppm signal for the Schiff base group and -355.2ppm for the nitrogen of the amine group). In this experiment the (SCN) nitrogen signal is invisible. The nitrogen chemical shift for the SCN- fragment depends on the chemical bonds present in the molecule. For the aliphatic thiocyanates (EtSCN), the nitrogen chemical shift is -102.0ppm, whereas for the isothiocyanate (Et(NCS)), this signal is shifted upfield to -277.0ppm . The ionic species NCS- has a nitrogen signal almost at the middle of this range, for example, K+NCS- δ N =-170ppm. The nitrogen chemical shifts of this fragment differ very much for the investigated complexes compared with simple model compounds, which means that the chemical bonds present in the complexes are much more complicated than those observed in simple aliphatic thiocyanates and isothiocyanates.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The simplest metal complex studied seems to be the one containing the Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion. In this case only three nitrogen signals in the solid state were found, which means that in this phase a symmetrical structure exists. Additionally, since this complex is diamagnetic, a planar four-bonded structure is suggested. The nitrogen chemical shift of the NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> fragment (−258.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm) shows that this fragment is bonded to the metal site across the nitrogen atom, similarly to isothiocyanate derivatives. A small, about 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, difference between the mentioned complex and Et(NCS) can be due to intermolecular, long-range interactions, for example some hydrogen bonds, and excludes chemical bonding through the sulfur atom. The strong upfield shift of the imine nitrogen signal suggests a very short Ni–N bond distance compared to such bonds in other similar complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The simplest metal complex studied seems to be the one containing the Ni2+ ion. In this case only three nitrogen signals in the solid state were found, which means that in this phase a symmetrical structure exists. Additionally, since this complex is diamagnetic, a planar four-bonded structure is suggested. The nitrogen chemical shift of the NCS- fragment (-258.6ppm) shows that this fragment is bonded to the metal site across the nitrogen atom, similarly to isothiocyanate derivatives. A small, about 20ppm, difference between the mentioned complex and Et(NCS) can be due to intermolecular, long-range interactions, for example some hydrogen bonds, and excludes chemical bonding through the sulfur atom. The strong upfield shift of the imine nitrogen signal suggests a very short Ni-N bond distance compared to such bonds in other similar complexes.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The second complex with the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation seems to be more complicated than the previous one. Three close pairs of signals were observed in the nitrogen solid-state spectrum, which means that a non-symmetric structure is present. The low field shift of two signals assigned to the imine groups indicates that the nitrogen–metal bonding is weaker than that observed in the nickel complex. The positions of the signals of the two (NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) fragments (about 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm downfield compared with the Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> complex) suggest that the (NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) fragment is still bonded to the metal site <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> the nitrogen atom, but its intramolecular contacts are stronger than those found in the nickel complex.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The second complex with the Zn2+ cation seems to be more complicated than the previous one. Three close pairs of signals were observed in the nitrogen solid-state spectrum, which means that a non-symmetric structure is present. The low field shift of two signals assigned to the imine groups indicates that the nitrogen-metal bonding is weaker than that observed in the nickel complex. The positions of the signals of the two (NCS-) fragments (about 40ppm downfield compared with the Ni2+ complex) suggest that the (NCS-) fragment is still bonded to the metal site via the nitrogen atom, but its intramolecular contacts are stronger than those found in the nickel complex.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The most interesting complex is the cadmium complex. In this case, five nitrogen signals were observed. The number of nitrogen signals shows a strongly asymmetric structure for this complex, but the differences in the appropriate values indicate that the structural differences are bigger than those in the zinc complex. First of all, only one signal from the imine moiety was found. This could be explained by an overlap of signals or by the fact that one of them is missing. On the base of the NMR spectra this problem cannot be solved. The appearance of couplings between the cadmium and imine and amine nitrogen atoms confirms that the cadmium atom is bonded to all the nitrogen atoms in the complex. The values of those couplings are typical for one-bond interactions. In the (SCN) moiety spectral range, two significantly separated signals are present. This means that two different (NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) fragments are present. One of the (SCN) fragments, connected with the −222.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm signal, is bonded with the cadmium site <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> the nitrogen atom, similarly to the previously discussed zinc complex, whereas the second one exhibits a different type of bonding. The nitrogen chemical shift of −182.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm shows that in this case the (SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) fragment can be bonded from both sides: via the nitrogen atom to one cadmium ion and by the sulphur atom to the second metal site. This statement leads to the conclusion that in this complex two different environments around the cadmium ions can be expected. To solve this problem <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd NMR experiments in DMSO solution and in the solid-state were done. In the <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd CP MAS spectrum two signals at −439.0 and −479.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm were detected. Unfortunately, on the base of CP MAS NMR data we are not able to decide the nature of this differentiation, it could be due to a different geometrical environment or a crystal packing effect. In DMSO solution only one <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd signal at −533.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm was found. A significant difference of the cadmium chemical shifts in the solid state and in solution suggests that in both phases the structures of the species are very different. In the proton and nitrogen spectra taken in DMSO solution, only one set of signals was found, indicating a single structure in this phase. This means that in the solid state two different structures of the Cd atoms are present, thus leading to an asymmetric structure, whereas in solution, probably due to fast exchange of CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and (SCN)<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions, only one dynamically averaged structure is observed. Comparing the <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd chemical shift of the species in DMSO solution with those obtained for the complex and cadmium acetate (<ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−707.34<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm) in the solid state we can assume that in DMSO solution some kind of complexation can take place, otherwise the <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd chemical shift of solution sample should be close to the <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−707.34<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm value. The nitrogen chemical shift of the imine atom in DMSO solution confirms this conclusion. The <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">N</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−122.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm value indicates some interaction with the Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion, for free imine moiety (without any interaction) a nitrogen chemical shift close to −50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm would be expected.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The most interesting complex is the cadmium complex. In this case, five nitrogen signals were observed. The number of nitrogen signals shows a strongly asymmetric structure for this complex, but the differences in the appropriate values indicate that the structural differences are bigger than those in the zinc complex. First of all, only one signal from the imine moiety was found. This could be explained by an overlap of signals or by the fact that one of them is missing. On the base of the NMR spectra this problem cannot be solved. The appearance of couplings between the cadmium and imine and amine nitrogen atoms confirms that the cadmium atom is bonded to all the nitrogen atoms in the complex. The values of those couplings are typical for one-bond interactions. In the (SCN) moiety spectral range, two significantly separated signals are present. This means that two different (NCS-) fragments are present. One of the (SCN) fragments, connected with the -222.3ppm signal, is bonded with the cadmium site via the nitrogen atom, similarly to the previously discussed zinc complex, whereas the second one exhibits a different type of bonding. The nitrogen chemical shift of -182.7ppm shows that in this case the (SCN-) fragment can be bonded from both sides: via the nitrogen atom to one cadmium ion and by the sulphur atom to the second metal site. This statement leads to the conclusion that in this complex two different environments around the cadmium ions can be expected. To solve this problem 113Cd NMR experiments in DMSO solution and in the solid-state were done. In the 113Cd CP MAS spectrum two signals at -439.0 and -479.6ppm were detected. Unfortunately, on the base of CP MAS NMR data we are not able to decide the nature of this differentiation, it could be due to a different geometrical environment or a crystal packing effect. In DMSO solution only one 113Cd signal at -533.3ppm was found. A significant difference of the cadmium chemical shifts in the solid state and in solution suggests that in both phases the structures of the species are very different. In the proton and nitrogen spectra taken in DMSO solution, only one set of signals was found, indicating a single structure in this phase. This means that in the solid state two different structures of the Cd atoms are present, thus leading to an asymmetric structure, whereas in solution, probably due to fast exchange of CH3COO- and (SCN)- anions, only one dynamically averaged structure is observed. Comparing the 113Cd chemical shift of the species in DMSO solution with those obtained for the complex and cadmium acetate (δ =-707.34ppm) in the solid state we can assume that in DMSO solution some kind of complexation can take place, otherwise the 113Cd chemical shift of solution sample should be close to the δ =-707.34ppm value. The nitrogen chemical shift of the imine atom in DMSO solution confirms this conclusion. The δ N =-122.4ppm value indicates some interaction with the Cd2+ ion, for free imine moiety (without any interaction) a nitrogen chemical shift close to -50ppm would be expected.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">For all the complexes, standard <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C CP MAS spectra and short contact time measurements were also collected. Three (aliphatic, aromatic and low field) well resolved groups of signals were found. From the point of view of the number of signals, the situation is similar to the one in the nitrogen spectra. For the zinc and cadmium complexes two sets of signals are present, and one set are present for the nickel complex. The low field region is the most interesting and informative where C-2 (formally C–O) and C-7 (–C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N–) signals are present. The chemical shifts of the C-2 atoms are known to be sensitive to the functionalization of the oxygen atom. Values close to 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm are expected for phenols, whereas for a carbonyl group the signal is strongly shifted downfield. The positions of those signals in the investigated complexes (Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>166.5 and 165.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>169.0 and 169.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>161.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm) indicate that in all cases the oxygen atom is differently involved in the complexation process. The other signals, aromatic and aliphatic, are in the typical ranges and do not supply valuable structural information.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For all the complexes, standard 13C CP MAS spectra and short contact time measurements were also collected. Three (aliphatic, aromatic and low field) well resolved groups of signals were found. From the point of view of the number of signals, the situation is similar to the one in the nitrogen spectra. For the zinc and cadmium complexes two sets of signals are present, and one set are present for the nickel complex. The low field region is the most interesting and informative where C-2 (formally C-O) and C-7 (-CN-) signals are present. The chemical shifts of the C-2 atoms are known to be sensitive to the functionalization of the oxygen atom. Values close to 150ppm are expected for phenols, whereas for a carbonyl group the signal is strongly shifted downfield. The positions of those signals in the investigated complexes (Zn2+ δ =166.5 and 165.9ppm, Cd2+ δ =169.0 and 169.4ppm, Ni2+ δ =161.9ppm) indicate that in all cases the oxygen atom is differently involved in the complexation process. The other signals, aromatic and aliphatic, are in the typical ranges and do not supply valuable structural information.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Concluding, on the basis of the NMR measurements in the solid state it is possible to decide which atoms are involved in the complexation process and to estimate the approximate symmetry of the complex. However, in order to obtain the exact structure, it is necessary to perform X-ray structural investigations.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Concluding, on the basis of the NMR measurements in the solid state it is possible to decide which atoms are involved in the complexation process and to estimate the approximate symmetry of the complex. However, in order to obtain the exact structure, it is necessary to perform X-ray structural investigations.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray diffraction studies – geometry</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Each investigated complex of the Schiff base and metal cation (Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>) has a different geometry and a different coordination pattern of the metal ions. The complexes with Zn(II) and Cd(II) form dimers in the crystalline state, whereas the Ni(II) complex exists as monomer (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The structure of Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> complex obtained by us is in contrast to the literature data  where a dimer structure was found.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray diffraction studies - geometry

Each investigated complex of the Schiff base and metal cation (Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+) has a different geometry and a different coordination pattern of the metal ions. The complexes with Zn(II) and Cd(II) form dimers in the crystalline state, whereas the Ni(II) complex exists as monomer ( ). The structure of Ni2+ complex obtained by us is in contrast to the literature data  where a dimer structure was found.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">In all the complexes, the metals are coordinated by the Schiff base molecular fragment (by two nitrogen and one oxygen atom) and by a nitrogen atom from the (SCN)<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion. For the <ce:bold>Ni(NCS)L</ce:bold> complex, four ligands coordinate nickel and form a square planar coordination (Figs.  and 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a). The Ni1 atoms lay in the plane created by the O1, N1, N2 ligand atoms. In the case of <ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold> both zinc atoms are coordinated by five ligands and form tetragonal pyramids (Figs.  and b). Each oxygen atom from the Schiff base coordinates two zinc atoms. The distance between Zn1 and Zn2 is equal to 3.179<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and between the O1 and O2 atoms 2.532<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The deviation of the Zn(II) atoms from the ligand planes (plane 1: O1, O2, N1, N2 and plane 2: O1, O2, N3, N4 – see Fig. 1a in the Supporting materials) is equal to 0.63 and 0.67<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Zn1 and Zn2, respectively. The angle between these planes is 62.91°. Also in the <ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold> (Figs.  and c) structure, each oxygen atom from the Schiff base is coordinated by two cadmium cations. The distances between Cd1…Cd2 and O1…O2 are equal to 3.418 and 2.820<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The Cd2 atom has a very similar coordination to the zinc atom coordination in <ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold> – five ligands and a tetragonal pyramidal geometry. The deviation of the Cd2 atom from the Schiff base plane is equal to 0.700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (see Fig. 1b in the Supporting materials). Surprisingly, the coordination of the Cd1 atom is different. Cd1 is located exactly in the plane defined by the O1, O2, N1, N2 atoms. Additionally, it is coordinated by a sulfur atom. The angle between planes 1 and 2 (defined in the same manner as for the zinc complex) is equal to 51.63°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In all the complexes, the metals are coordinated by the Schiff base molecular fragment (by two nitrogen and one oxygen atom) and by a nitrogen atom from the (SCN)- anion. For the Ni(NCS)L complex, four ligands coordinate nickel and form a square planar coordination (Figs.  and  a). The Ni1 atoms lay in the plane created by the O1, N1, N2 ligand atoms. In the case of Zn2(NCS)2L2  both zinc atoms are coordinated by five ligands and form tetragonal pyramids (Figs.  and b). Each oxygen atom from the Schiff base coordinates two zinc atoms. The distance between Zn1 and Zn2 is equal to 3.179Å, and between the O1 and O2 atoms 2.532Å. The deviation of the Zn(II) atoms from the ligand planes (plane 1: O1, O2, N1, N2 and plane 2: O1, O2, N3, N4 - see Fig. 1a in the Supporting materials) is equal to 0.63 and 0.67Å for Zn1 and Zn2, respectively. The angle between these planes is 62.91°. Also in the Cd2(NCS)2L2  (Figs.  and c) structure, each oxygen atom from the Schiff base is coordinated by two cadmium cations. The distances between Cd1…Cd2 and O1…O2 are equal to 3.418 and 2.820Å, respectively. The Cd2 atom has a very similar coordination to the zinc atom coordination in Zn2(NCS)2L2  - five ligands and a tetragonal pyramidal geometry. The deviation of the Cd2 atom from the Schiff base plane is equal to 0.700Å (see Fig. 1b in the Supporting materials). Surprisingly, the coordination of the Cd1 atom is different. Cd1 is located exactly in the plane defined by the O1, O2, N1, N2 atoms. Additionally, it is coordinated by a sulfur atom. The angle between planes 1 and 2 (defined in the same manner as for the zinc complex) is equal to 51.63°.

elements.content:

One can see that the bond lengths between the metal and ligands atoms in <ce:bold>Ni(NCS)L</ce:bold> are shorter than the respective bond lengths in <ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

</ce:bold>. For <ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>, the ligand–metal–ligand angles are more deviated from 90° than in the case of the other complexes. The C–O bond lengths vary from 1.318<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for <ce:bold>Ni(NCS)L</ce:bold> to 1.327<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for <ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold> and up to 1.351<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for <ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A comparison of selected bond distances and angles for the three complexes is illustrated in  . In general, the bond lengths in the aromatic rings are similar for all compounds. One can see that the bond lengths between the metal and ligands atoms in Ni(NCS)L are shorter than the respective bond lengths in Zn2(NCS)2L2  and Cd2(NCS)2L2 . For Cd2(NCS)2L2 , the ligand-metal-ligand angles are more deviated from 90° than in the case of the other complexes. <ce:section-title>Crystal packing</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>
<ce:bold>Ni(NCS)L</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">This complex crystallises in the monoclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group with one independent molecule in the asymmetric part of the unit cell. From the view along the <ce:italic>y</ce:italic> axis it is easy to observe that molecules form two types of layers – aromatic and polar ones (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). The aromatic part of each molecule of this complex is related by the centres of symmetry with two neighbouring molecules and by the 2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> screw axis perpendicular to the <ce:italic>xy</ce:italic> plane with another molecule. Such symmetry allows for very efficient face-to-face π…π stacking interactions between two molecules related by an inversion centre (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>a). The distance between two parallel planes defined by the benzene ring atoms is equal to 3.523<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is typical for such stacking interactions. The 3D network is stabilized by weak intermolecular interactions: C–H…O, C–H…C (b and 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal packing

 Ni(NCS)L 

This complex crystallises in the monoclinic P21/c space group with one independent molecule in the asymmetric part of the unit cell. From the view along the y axis it is easy to observe that molecules form two types of layers - aromatic and polar ones ( ). The aromatic part of each molecule of this complex is related by the centres of symmetry with two neighbouring molecules and by the 21 screw axis perpendicular to the xy plane with another molecule. Such symmetry allows for very efficient face-to-face π…π stacking interactions between two molecules related by an inversion centre ( a). The distance between two parallel planes defined by the benzene ring atoms is equal to 3.523Å, which is typical for such stacking interactions. The 3D network is stabilized by weak intermolecular interactions: C-H…O, C-H…C (b and  ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>
<ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The complex <ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold> crystallises in the monoclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> space group with one molecule in the asymmetric part of the unit cell. From the view along the <ce:italic>x</ce:italic> direction (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>a) it is seen that all the (SCN)<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands are directed in the same direction, i.e., towards the Schiff base fragment. This apparently helps to pack the molecules efficiently in the crystal lattice. Molecules lay along the <ce:italic>y</ce:italic> axis and are related by a 2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> screw axis. Such a molecular arrangement results in a number of short contacts between the (SCN)<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand and the hydrogen atoms from the Schiff base fragment. Also some short C–H…C interactions between the neighbouring Schiff base fragments can be observed (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>a and ). No π…π stacking appears in this structure. All the sulfur atoms are relatively far from the zinc atoms (<ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and they do not belong to the coordination sphere of the Zn(II) centre.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Zn2(NCS)2L2  

The complex Zn2(NCS)2L2  crystallises in the monoclinic P21 space group with one molecule in the asymmetric part of the unit cell. From the view along the x direction ( a) it is seen that all the (SCN)- ligands are directed in the same direction, i.e., towards the Schiff base fragment. This apparently helps to pack the molecules efficiently in the crystal lattice. Molecules lay along the y axis and are related by a 21 screw axis. Such a molecular arrangement results in a number of short contacts between the (SCN)- ligand and the hydrogen atoms from the Schiff base fragment. Also some short C-H…C interactions between the neighbouring Schiff base fragments can be observed ( a and ). No π…π stacking appears in this structure. All the sulfur atoms are relatively far from the zinc atoms (ca. 5Å) and they do not belong to the coordination sphere of the Zn(II) centre.

<ce:section-title>
<ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">This complex crystallises in the monoclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> space group with one independent molecule in the asymmetric part of the unit cell. The molecular arrangement in the crystal lattice is slightly similar to the one in the complex <ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>: the (SCN)<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands are all directed in the same direction – towards the Schiff base fragments (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>a), thus forming an infinite ribbon in the crystal lattice. Also the shortest intermolecular contacts are present between (SCN)<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and the hydrogen atoms from the Schiff base (see b and ). However, in this case, the distance between one of the sulfur atoms from (SCN)<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and the closest cadmium atom from the neighbouring molecule is equal only to 2.684<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. As a consequence, the sulfur atom is also coordinated by Cd(II). The coordination of the two cadmium cations in this molecule is different. No π…π stacking appears in this structure. In the <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> direction some empty channels are observed in the 3D structure of the <ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold> complex (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>b). The size of the channel is <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 3.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å when only heavy atoms are considered (see Fig. 2a in the Supporting material). When the hydrogen atoms are also taken into account, it turns out that the distances between the closest hydrogen atoms from the methyl groups are close to 2.610 and 2.849<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (see Fig. 2b in the Supporting materials). As a consequence, the channels are too narrow to host any solvent molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cd2(NCS)2L2  

This complex crystallises in the monoclinic P21/n space group with one independent molecule in the asymmetric part of the unit cell. The molecular arrangement in the crystal lattice is slightly similar to the one in the complex Zn2(NCS)2L2 : the (SCN)- ligands are all directed in the same direction - towards the Schiff base fragments (see  a), thus forming an infinite ribbon in the crystal lattice. Also the shortest intermolecular contacts are present between (SCN)- and the hydrogen atoms from the Schiff base (see b and ). However, in this case, the distance between one of the sulfur atoms from (SCN)- and the closest cadmium atom from the neighbouring molecule is equal only to 2.684Å. As a consequence, the sulfur atom is also coordinated by Cd(II). The coordination of the two cadmium cations in this molecule is different. No π…π stacking appears in this structure. In the z direction some empty channels are observed in the 3D structure of the Cd2(NCS)2L2  complex (see  b). The size of the channel is ca. 3.4×5.5Å when only heavy atoms are considered (see Fig. 2a in the Supporting material). When the hydrogen atoms are also taken into account, it turns out that the distances between the closest hydrogen atoms from the methyl groups are close to 2.610 and 2.849Å (see Fig. 2b in the Supporting materials). As a consequence, the channels are too narrow to host any solvent molecules.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">We have studied a series of three model metal complexes, <ce:bold>Ni(NCS)L</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>, consisting of the SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion(s) and L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2-[(2-dimethylaminoethylimino)-methyl]-phenolate(s), where M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>. The metal cations in these complexes have different coordination modes. The Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation in <ce:bold>Ni(NCS)L</ce:bold> has almost a square-planar coordination, the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation in <ce:bold>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold> is pentacoordinated by three nitrogen and two oxygen atoms, whereas Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> is penta- and hexacoordinated in <ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>. It appears that these different coordination modes influence the chemical shifts of the metal cations (if available) and also the nitrogen atoms present in these complexes. The different symmetries of the investigated complexes are manifested in the solid state NMR spectra by the number of signals observed. Additionally, some chemical shift values can be correlated with the M–N and M–O bond lengths, but only on a qualitative level. Summarising the presented results, we can state that both methods under study deliver different kind of data. If we have crystals good enough for X-ray single crystal measurement, we can obtain full structural information not available by other methods, but if we only have powder samples then heteronuclear solid state CP MAS NMR experiments can be the method of choice. By complex analysis of all the available NMR chemical shifts we can define the chemical bonds, scheme and symmetry of the molecule, which leads to a conclusion close to the X-ray results, but all of the time we have to remember that the NMR data have only qualitative character. Sometimes heteronuclear coupling constants can be very useful in such elucidations (for example, in the cadmium complexes). Unfortunately, the available database of such couplings is rather limited, which drastically limits their application. Typical solid state CP MAS NMR analysis generally is based on chemical shift values, where it is very easy to compare the results obtained in the solid state with measurements taken for solutions. This comparison is very simple and reliable because in both phases we can analyse the same spectral parameters.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have studied a series of three model metal complexes, Ni(NCS)L, Zn2(NCS)2L2  and Cd2(NCS)2L2 , consisting of the SCN- anion(s) and L=2-[(2-dimethylaminoethylimino)-methyl]-phenolate(s), where M=Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+. The metal cations in these complexes have different coordination modes. The Ni2+ cation in Ni(NCS)L has almost a square-planar coordination, the Zn2+ cation in Zn2(NCS)2L2  is pentacoordinated by three nitrogen and two oxygen atoms, whereas Cd2+ is penta- and hexacoordinated in Cd2(NCS)2L2 . It appears that these different coordination modes influence the chemical shifts of the metal cations (if available) and also the nitrogen atoms present in these complexes. The different symmetries of the investigated complexes are manifested in the solid state NMR spectra by the number of signals observed. Additionally, some chemical shift values can be correlated with the M-N and M-O bond lengths, but only on a qualitative level. Summarising the presented results, we can state that both methods under study deliver different kind of data. If we have crystals good enough for X-ray single crystal measurement, we can obtain full structural information not available by other methods, but if we only have powder samples then heteronuclear solid state CP MAS NMR experiments can be the method of choice. By complex analysis of all the available NMR chemical shifts we can define the chemical bonds, scheme and symmetry of the molecule, which leads to a conclusion close to the X-ray results, but all of the time we have to remember that the NMR data have only qualitative character. Sometimes heteronuclear coupling constants can be very useful in such elucidations (for example, in the cadmium complexes). Unfortunately, the available database of such couplings is rather limited, which drastically limits their application. Typical solid state CP MAS NMR analysis generally is based on chemical shift values, where it is very easy to compare the results obtained in the solid state with measurements taken for solutions. This comparison is very simple and reliable because in both phases we can analyse the same spectral parameters.

</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

Supplementary data

The supporting information contains figures illustrating the differences in the coordination of the Zn and Cd cations in Zn2(NCS)2L2  and Cd2(NCS)2L2 , channels formed in the Cd2(NCS)2L2  structure and tables defining the numerical values of bond lengths and valence angles in all structures. CCDC 805133-805135 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for all three complexes. These data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html, or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

cln_elements.clean_text:
For all the complexes, standard 13C CP MAS spectra and short contact time measurements were also collected. Three (aliphatic, aromatic and low field) well resolved groups of signals were found. From the point of view of the number of signals, the situation is similar to the one in the nitrogen spectra. For the zinc and cadmium complexes two sets of signals are present, and one set are present for the nickel complex. The low field region is the most interesting and informative where C-2 (formally C-O) and C-7 (-CN-) signals are present. The chemical shifts of the C-2 atoms are known to be sensitive to the functionalization of the oxygen atom. Values close to 150ppm are expected for phenols, whereas for a carbonyl group the signal is strongly shifted downfield. The positions of those signals in the investigated complexes (Zn2+ δ =166.5 and 165.9ppm, Cd2+ δ =169.0 and 169.4ppm, Ni2+ δ =161.9ppm) indicate that in all cases the oxygen atom is differently involved in the complexation process. The other signals, aromatic and aliphatic, are in the typical ranges and do not supply valuable structural information.

In all the complexes, the metals are coordinated by the Schiff base molecular fragment (by two nitrogen and one oxygen atom) and by a nitrogen atom from the (SCN)- anion. For the Ni(NCS)L complex, four ligands coordinate nickel and form a square planar coordination (Figs.  and  a). The Ni1 atoms lay in the plane created by the O1, N1, N2 ligand atoms. In the case of Zn2(NCS)2L2  both zinc atoms are coordinated by five ligands and form tetragonal pyramids (Figs.  and b). Each oxygen atom from the Schiff base coordinates two zinc atoms. The distance between Zn1 and Zn2 is equal to 3.179Å, and between the O1 and O2 atoms 2.532Å. The deviation of the Zn(II) atoms from the ligand planes (plane 1: O1, O2, N1, N2 and plane 2: O1, O2, N3, N4 - see Fig. 1a in the Supporting materials) is equal to 0.63 and 0.67Å for Zn1 and Zn2, respectively. The angle between these planes is 62.91°. Also in the Cd2(NCS)2L2  (Figs.  and c) structure, each oxygen atom from the Schiff base is coordinated by two cadmium cations. The distances between Cd1…Cd2 and O1…O2 are equal to 3.418 and 2.820Å, respectively. The Cd2 atom has a very similar coordination to the zinc atom coordination in Zn2(NCS)2L2  - five ligands and a tetragonal pyramidal geometry. The deviation of the Cd2 atom from the Schiff base plane is equal to 0.700Å (see Fig. 1b in the Supporting materials). Surprisingly, the coordination of the Cd1 atom is different. Cd1 is located exactly in the plane defined by the O1, O2, N1, N2 atoms. Additionally, it is coordinated by a sulfur atom. The angle between planes 1 and 2 (defined in the same manner as for the zinc complex) is equal to 51.63°.

A comparison of selected bond distances and angles for the three complexes is illustrated in  . In general, the bond lengths in the aromatic rings are similar for all compounds. One can see that the bond lengths between the metal and ligands atoms in Ni(NCS)L are shorter than the respective bond lengths in Zn2(NCS)2L2  and Cd2(NCS)2L2 . For Cd2(NCS)2L2 , the ligand-metal-ligand angles are more deviated from 90° than in the case of the other complexes. The C-O bond lengths vary from 1.318Å for Ni(NCS)L to 1.327Å for Cd2(NCS)2L2  and up to 1.351Å for Zn2(NCS)2L2 .

 Zn2(NCS)2L2  

The complex Zn2(NCS)2L2  crystallises in the monoclinic P21 space group with one molecule in the asymmetric part of the unit cell. From the view along the x direction ( a) it is seen that all the (SCN)- ligands are directed in the same direction, i.e., towards the Schiff base fragment. This apparently helps to pack the molecules efficiently in the crystal lattice. Molecules lay along the y axis and are related by a 21 screw axis. Such a molecular arrangement results in a number of short contacts between the (SCN)- ligand and the hydrogen atoms from the Schiff base fragment. Also some short C-H…C interactions between the neighbouring Schiff base fragments can be observed ( a and ). No π…π stacking appears in this structure. All the sulfur atoms are relatively far from the zinc atoms (ca. 5Å) and they do not belong to the coordination sphere of the Zn(II) centre.

 Cd2(NCS)2L2  

This complex crystallises in the monoclinic P21/n space group with one independent molecule in the asymmetric part of the unit cell. The molecular arrangement in the crystal lattice is slightly similar to the one in the complex Zn2(NCS)2L2 : the (SCN)- ligands are all directed in the same direction - towards the Schiff base fragments (see  a), thus forming an infinite ribbon in the crystal lattice. Also the shortest intermolecular contacts are present between (SCN)- and the hydrogen atoms from the Schiff base (see b and ). However, in this case, the distance between one of the sulfur atoms from (SCN)- and the closest cadmium atom from the neighbouring molecule is equal only to 2.684Å. As a consequence, the sulfur atom is also coordinated by Cd(II). The coordination of the two cadmium cations in this molecule is different. No π…π stacking appears in this structure. In the z direction some empty channels are observed in the 3D structure of the Cd2(NCS)2L2  complex (see  b). The size of the channel is ca. 3.4×5.5Å when only heavy atoms are considered (see Fig. 2a in the Supporting material). When the hydrogen atoms are also taken into account, it turns out that the distances between the closest hydrogen atoms from the methyl groups are close to 2.610 and 2.849Å (see Fig. 2b in the Supporting materials). As a consequence, the channels are too narrow to host any solvent molecules.

</ce:caption>
<tgroup cols="4">

</entry>

<entry xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd">−122.0, −132.3</entry>
<entry xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd">−115.1 (152<hsp sp="0.25"></hsp>Hz)</entry>
</row>
<row valign="top">
<entry xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd">NCS<sup loc="post">−</sup>/SCN<sup loc="post">−</sup>
</entry>
<entry xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd">−258.6</entry>
<entry xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd">−216.8, −222.9</entry>
<entry xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd">−182.7, −222.3</entry>
</row>
<row valign="top">
<entry xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd">CH<inf loc="post">2</inf>–CH<inf loc="post">2</inf>–N–(Me)<inf loc="post">2</inf>

<entry xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd">−352.4 (130<hsp sp="0.25"></hsp>Hz), −357.1 (114<hsp sp="0.25"></hsp>Hz)</entry>
</row>

</tgroup>
<ce:legend>
<ce:simple-para id="sp075" view="all">In brackets <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">N–Cd</ce:inf> coupling constants measured from satellite lines.</ce:simple-para>
<ce:simple-para id="sp080" view="all">In DMSO solution of the Cd complex, two nitrogen signals: −122.4 and −355.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm were detected.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:legend>
</ce:table>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Table 2. Nitrogen chemical shifts of the investigated complexes in the solid state.

| Position/cation | Ni<sup>2+</sup> | Zn<sup>2+</sup> | Cd<sup>2+</sup> |
|-----------------|-----------------|-----------------|-----------------|
| –CH=dbndN–      | −203.5          | −122.0, −132.3   | −115.1 (152Hz)   |
| NCS<sup>−</sup>/SCN<sup>−</sup> | −258.6 | −216.8, −222.9 | −182.7, −222.3 |
| CH2–CH2–N–(Me)2 | −376.5          | −354.8, −355.6   | −352.4 (130Hz), −357.1 (114Hz) |

In brackets <sup>1</sup> J N–Cd coupling constants measured from satellite lines.
In DMSO solution of the Cd complex, two nitrogen signals: −122.4 and −355.2ppm were detected.
